Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Robustness Analysis of Uncertain Programs: Theory, Algorithms, and Tools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This research program will develop mathematical techniques to automatically prove the robustness of computer programs operating under uncertainty. The aim is to bridge the gap between control-theoretic studies of robustness, on the one hand, and program semantics and analysis on the other. In cyberphysical systems, where sensor-derived data from the physical world is intertwined with computations, uncertainty arises from volatile or erroneous sensor data. Such systems demand predictable responses to perturbations of the system's initial conditions, otherwise they will be unreliable. The project has three themes: (1) Theory: It will create comprehensive semantics of robustness properties such as continuity and stability in the setting of imperative programs over complex data types. (2) Algorithms: Analysis algorithms are needed to prove robustness of programs, or alternately find violations of robustness. Scalable, lightweight analyses will be developed along with precise but heavyweight methods. (3) Tools: These analyses will be implemented in tools applicable to software for real-world cyber-physical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On the scientific front, the intellectual merit outcomes of our project include the following.


* This project was one of the early efforts on the study of robustness analysis of software. A program is robust in the present sense if its behavior does not change significantly under changes to its inputs. While robustness is a standard concern in control, therobustness of programs was a new concern when this project was firstfunded. This project played a key role in the flowering of this topicinto a research area. The area continues to be active, as evidenced by the many papers on this topic published at important scientific venuesin recent times, and thriving workshops such as Design and Analysis of Robust Systems (DARS).

* A key early contribution of the project was to formulate robustness in terms of analytic properties such as continuity [POPL-10] and Lipschitz-continuity [FSE-11], and to show that these properties can be verified using a form of relational reasoning about programs. These formulations were well-received in the scientific community: the FSE-11 paper won a SIGSOFT Distinguished Paper award, and a paper unifying the POPL-10 and FSE-11 articles was published at Communications of the ACM as a Research Highlight. The papers have gathered a significant number of citations.

* Since these initial results, the award supported several otherresults on robustness analysis of programs. Specifically, the award supported work on automata-theoretic robustness analysis for finite-state string transducers (ATVA-13) and networked cyber-physical systems (VMCAI-13). The award also supported robustness analysis for programs, such as algorithms from computational geometry, that make sequences of discrete decisions under uncertainty (POPL-14).

* This award supported work on foundational algorithms whose applications go beyond robustness analysis, including the use of finite automata to represent and analyze real functions (LICS-13), and the development of techniques for solving Horn constraints (POPL-14).

* The award supported a new form of program analysis of cyber-physical systems based on "infinitesimals" (VMCAI-16).

* Finally, work supported in the last year of the project studied notions of robustness for multi-agent systems with incentives, and explored the relationships between robustness and game-theoretic notions of equilibria.

---

The broader impacts of our project include:

1) Training and professional development of graduate and undergraduate researchers.  The award supported a number of PhD students (Yanxin Lu, Suguman Bansal), masters students (Sara Navidpour), undergrad students (Richard Zhang), and visiting students (Anand Degwekar, Martin Nikoltchev, Martin Clochard).

2) Undergraduate and graduate courses. The award supported thedevelopment of several courses, including an undergraduate class at Penn State on "Concepts of Programming Languages", a graduate course at Rice on "Computer-Aided program design", and several graduate seminars.

3) Software. The award supported the development of several software systems, in particular a system for quantative robustness analysis of programs.

4) Workshops. The award supported the organization of multiple research workshops on topics related to robustness analysis, most notably the workshop on Numerical Software Verification, 2012, whichthe PI chaired, and the 1st SIGPLAN Workshop on Probabilistic and Approximate Computing.
